utterances: Hi.
And so the same people who collect meteorites often tend to like the pieces they get hit as well, and that it offers the full story.
You own the rock and you own the thing that the rock destroyed.
I understand that there's a chunk of the only meteorite ever to have killed a cow.
Well…
(Soundbite of laughter)
On auction.
At least they're not selling the cow.
No, but if a lot of these - the moon rocks, the Mars rocks, pieces that have hit actual items - it's all about the story.
It's all about being able to have an item that has an interesting story behind it.
It was just a piece of rock.
Well, it would not be anything - there wouldn't be anything more than a rock you find on the street.
But that rock word, meteorite, already has a story that it's traveled all these thousands and millions of miles through space to find its way on Earth.
And then damn the probability, but that it actually hit something that people can relate to.
It hit a cow.
It hit a car.
It hit a mailbox.
Aside…
…instead of just hitting the ground.
Aside from an actual piece of moon rock, as a collector, what do you think is the most desired artifact that anybody would like to own?

From the space program, I think, that - of the most desirable is an item that has been to the surface of the moon that is man-made because it represents the greatest accomplishment that we've been able to do as a species.
For most - for some people they believe that to be true.
I believe that to be true.

I think that we put all our efforts into something that was positive for the world that increased our knowledge and that was a representation of our being not just Americans or Russians, but being a one world, going for all mankind, as they said, going to the moon.

And so items that have been to the surface of the moon that have touched that dust and the rocks, but have, both were man-made, are testament to the same type of activity as Columbus coming across the ocean to the new world, or Magellan circling the world, or any of the great exploration.
Could you not see a business then of just sending artifacts to the moon and bringing them back and selling them?
Well, there is an attempt to try to start that now.
First, just getting to space.

There are companies that are now operating private suborbital vehicles that are launching objects first and then later in the next few years hopefully humans themselves, with their souvenirs intact, to space and back on 45-minute to hour-and-a-half-long jaunts.
But there's also commercial efforts to try to send things to the moon.
We just heard recently about a prize, the X - Google Lunar X Prize to send a rover to the moon and that has the goal of sending a rover there just to have it send back video.
I'd love to see the next prize be - send a rover there to pick up some of the dust and rocks and bring them back to Earth so that they could become that next collectible.
Oh, we'll have to wait and see.
I want to thank you very much for taking time to talk with us.
My pleasure.
Good luck to you.
Robert Pearlman is founder and editor of collectSpace.com.
He's a member of the U.S.
Space Walk of Fame Foundation Board of Directors and serves on the induction committee for the U.S.
Astronaut Hall of Fame.
In Texas, this was going to be one of the best years farmers had seen in a long time.
The cotton crop was projected to bring in record prices and even clear out many families' debt.
But as NPR's Carrie Kahn reports, the massive rainfall, winds and slow drying-out process have left many farmers overwhelmed and worried.
At Al-T's Cajun seafood restaurant in Winnie, Texas, the place is packed even though lunchtime has long come and gone.
(CROSSTALK)
No one is in a hurry to get back to their fields.
They can't.
They're flooded.
David Murrell says nearly 400 acres of his rice are totally submerged.
There's not much we can do.
We're still waiting on the water to go down so by road we can get into these fields.
We've got - our roads cross a gulley out at the farm, and the water is still too deep for us to get through it.
Luckily Murrell had just harvested some of his rice before Harvey dumped nearly 50 inches here.
But fourth-generation cattle and rice farmer Gerald Bauer decided to bring his cows in first, then cut his rice crop.
Unfortunately, he says, he miscalculated by one week.
A normal year - we're fine.
We can get in, cut it.
We're not late.
But Mother Nature decided we were late this year.
For Adam Leger, who runs an aerial fumigation service with his brother, they won't know for weeks if any of their equipment is salvageable.
Four of his crop dusters are under water at the local airport.
I've never seen it - nothing like this.
I don't think anybody in here has seen it.
It will take months, maybe even a full year to get final figures on Texas' agriculture losses to Harvey.
Gene Hall is with the Texas Farm Bureau.
I did some back-of-the-envelope calculations.
I completely understand it.

But even for those people, even for the people who say, you know what, Weiner, I never want to vote for you again, I even want them to read my ideas and think about what they want in the next mayor and to have...
The next mayor who might be Anthony Weiner.
A recent poll shows him leading the Democratic field; another has him running second to Quinn.
And there's a third Democrat who's mounting a serious charge.
So without further ado, Bill Thompson.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHEERING)
Thank you.
Our candidate for mayor.
Former city comptroller Bill Thompson has racked up some major endorsements, including one earlier this week from the Transport Workers Union.
These are the working, middle-class New Yorkers who continue to be squeezed each and every day.
And we need to stand with them and make sure that this city continues to bounce back for all New Yorkers.
Thompson would be the city's first African-American mayor in a generation.
He won the Democratic nomination four years ago, but he's running a distant third this year.
It's unlikely that any of the Democratic hopefuls will get enough votes on September 10 to avoid a runoff election.
That means the top two finishers will probably face off again in early October.
And Hunter College's Ken Sherrill expects a big fight to the finish.
The mud will be flowing, blood will be splattering.
It'll be great fun.
Joel Rose, NPR News, New York.
Now an update on the ongoing news this hour.
A passenger jet crashed while it was landing earlier morning at San Francisco International Airport.
At this time, there are reports of at least two fatalities and area hospitals have received at least 70 people with injuries, as many as 10 of them critical.
At a press conference this evening, Debbie Hersman of the National transportation Safety Board said the agency has very little information at this point.
We're certainly going to be looking at the aircraft to try to find the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorders are functioning at the time of the accident.
We'll be looking to get information from them as well as document the accident scene.
Debbie Hersman, part of the National Transportation Safety Board team that will be investigating the crash.
Passenger Elliott Stone was on the plan and spoke to CNN.
Well, the first announcement was, everybody stay calm.
We were like, what?
We're - and everyone was leaving still, just buckle up and - or buckled out and just rushed out the doors.
There wasn't any slides or anything.
We didn't have a slide.
We just jumped off.
Passenger Elliott Stone talking to CNN.
The Asiana Airlines jet was coming from Seoul, South Korea.
People were seeing escaping the aircraft through emergency exit slides.
Flights are delayed at airports across the country as a result of the crash.
We'll get the latest from San Francisco coming up.
And now to Russia, where a U.S.
Embassy employee has been ordered to leave the country, this after Russian authorities nabbed him in a highly publicized arrest.
They charge the American as a CIA agent who was caught trying to recruit a Russian spy.
NPR's Corey Flintoff tells us more.
